top_reviews.title: Lovers of maritime and architectural history - stop here!
top_reviews.review: This museum will appeal to lovers of both maritime/naval and architectural history. Situated in the restored Barcelona Royal Shipyard buildings (construction started in the 13th century), this museum will particularly appeal to those interested in the days of the galleys, leading up to the Battle of Lepanto (1571), and naval warfare in the western Mediterranean. The key feature is a replica galley built in 1971 to commemorate Lepanto's 400th anniversary. There are also exhibits covering the transition from sail to steam and Spain's (particularly Catalonia's) role in developing a global empire and trading network. Definitely worth a visit! It is appropriately situated next to the monument celebrating Christopher Columbus!

top_reviews.title: Shame on the Maritime Museum
top_reviews.review: I visited your museum on September 10. I was horrified at the museum display comparing the explorers to tech giants. Tech giants work in air-conditioned offices while sipping coffee. The explorers sailed into the unknown, on ships that started to deteriorate immediately, and always ran out of food. The museum bashes both equally. I am no fan of tech giants, but they are successful entrepreneurs. Shame on your museum. By the way, I am female.

top_reviews.title: Barcelona martimes
top_reviews.review: Beautiful Building from the outside. Bit diffucult to find dur to constriction site of Barcelona. Its really gigantic and a lot of stuff to see. And for 10 Euro one of the Best Museum in Barcelona. Must have i would say.

top_reviews.title: Limited interest, but an amazing Galley and only 10 Euro to enter
top_reviews.review: Visited on Monday 20/11/23 10 Euro entry fee. The building housing the Museum, the Drassanes Reials de Barcelona (Royal Shipyards of Barcelona), is a Gothic architectural complex built over 700 years ago, the contents of which focused on the activities at the site over the years as well as housing a recreation of the Royal Galley. The Royal Galley is the highlight and it's interesting the details of how the Spanish viewed the British decision to ban slavery, as the text on descriptions of the Spanish attitude to it appears to glorify the Spanish attempts to avoid the impacts of that ban.

top_reviews.title: Great museum, restaurant understaffed
top_reviews.review: We chiefly wanted to incorporate visiting this museum into our exploration of the waterfront to try the menu del dia as recommended by roadtripspainandportugal.com , one of the YouTube channels we watched before our trip. However, we made the classic tourist mistake of forgetting that museums on weekdays can be full of school parties! The museum itself is very well presented, and it's great to see the old shipbuilding sheds reused while keeping their link with matters nautical. It would be a great option for a rainy ( or too hot) day if you want to give your kids space to run around. Once we had seen enough of the exhibits we went to the restaurant and were alarmed to see a lot of tables with "reserved" signs, while most of the rest were occupied, including one large school party. In fairness to the staff they did find us a table quickly, but they were clearly understaffed as in the 15 minutes we sat there no- one brought us a menu. One member of staff was behind the bar one collected frozen desserts for the school party and the other was rushing about, but I was not sure why. After 15 minutes, with no menu and not having seen any orders taken OR delivered to the other tables, we gave up and went elsewhere.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful museum
top_reviews.review: Love this museum- it explains 700 years of history, has beautiful exhibits and a lovely garden area and restaurant. Located close to the beach. Very informative. And the Spanish Galleon is amazing when you step into the main building. You can go up to the top of the ship on platforms to view it from above. Tickets are inexpensive.

top_reviews.title: Interesting, but not a Must
top_reviews.review: We visited the museum, because it was free on Sundays. The documentation and explanation of the exhibits leaves much to be desidered and follows rather old concepts. The motion picture is nice, but of littel information value. The by far best exhibits is the replica of the Lepanto galley that served Juan d'Austria as flagship.

top_reviews.title: Excellent museum capturing the maritime history
top_reviews.review: We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this wonderful museum. The building and site housing the museum has its own amazing history and is perfect for capturing the maritime history of this area. The cost was only 10 euros and was worth every cent as the museum has so much to offer

name: Museu Picasso
description: The Museu Picasso in Barcelona is a key reference for understanding the formative years of Pablo Picasso. The genius of the young artist is revealed through the 4,251 works that make up the permanent collection. Furthermore, the Museu Picasso, opened in 1963, also reveals his deep relationship with Barcelona: an intimate, solid relationship that was shaped in his adolescence and youth, and continued until his death. The Museum is very rich in regard to work from the formative years in the life of the artist; it is practically exhaustive up to the Blue Period. The Museum also houses an important representation of works from 1917, and the series Las Meninas (1957) as well as a comprehensive print collection.

top_reviews.title: Go if you rate Picasso
top_reviews.review: Go if you rate Picasso. It will not give you an overview of his life and work as it largely consists of some interesting early work and some from the 1950's and later so is curiously disjointed. There is a very interesting section of his obsession with Velazquez's La Meninas which would have been much enhanced if there had been a large photo of the original. The building is worth a visit and the area around the museum is well worth exploring with lots of interesting artisanal shops I would suggest going along and seeing when the timed tickets are available (usually a few hours later) which gives you time to visit other local sights or wander around the local narrow streets

top_reviews.title: Nice enough but too crowded!
top_reviews.review: I made a reservation to come at a time when the museum wasÅt supposed to be busy, I am not sure what busy means. In an old absolutely stunning building there were crowds everywhere. The show in itself was nice enough but unfortunately not my favorite. I would still recommend going but to expect crowds.

top_reviews.title: A vast disappointment for a Picasso fan
top_reviews.review: This was the greatest disappointment of our trip. I had read that there were more than 4,000 permanent exhibits in 5 separate palaces, but I would guess that there were no more than 300 full-sized paintings in one building. Don't pass by the first room that is wallpapered with hundreds of thumbnail sketches or you will have missed half the tour. Most of the works were from his early years and were donated by Picasso himself so I would imagine that these were the ones that didn't sell. There were signs describing his most productive years then the next room jumped 3 decades of his career. We were going at a decent pace because we were expecting to see far more works of art, but we were finished in a little more than 1/2 an hour. When we asked if there was more to be seen, no one spoke much English and we were directed to the exit.

top_reviews.title: More than just a greatest hits...
top_reviews.review: The Picasso Museum was not at all what I expected, in a good way! I get to see a lot of Picasso's work living in Philadelphia as quite a few of his pieces are on display at the Barnes and the Philadelphia museum of art. However, honestly those collections are quite focused and do not tell me much about the man himself. I loved how the Picasso Museum walked you through his life and influences. You'll see more than just his most googled works. You'll see how things started, sketches from art school, and even his pottery! While I cannot remember the exact amount, admission was fairly priced. I'd plan to spend at least a hour, maybe an hour and a half, in the museum. They have a few videos around the museum mixed in with all the art to provide context and background. Enjoy!

top_reviews.title: Well worth a visit
top_reviews.review: The regular ticket price seems to be â¬14, but I went on a free Wednesday so I didn't have to pay anything to visit the museum. With that said it was definitely worth spending an hour there. To get a free ticket you need to to book in advance, but that is really easily done on the web page. On the web page it says that free times are Thursdays from 1700 to 1900 HRS, but when I booked all of Wednesday was free... You also get to se some MorÃ³ originals as well as Picasso.

top_reviews.title: Decent experience
top_reviews.review: This is a nice museum that is easy to experience. We bought our tickets for a later time of the day and it wasn't over crowded. They control admission to allow everyone a chance to actually spend time looking at the art and reading the descriptions and captions. Plan on an hour and a half or two hours.

top_reviews.title: Wonderful museum
top_reviews.review: We enjoyed our visit to the Picasso Museum and our expectations were definitely met. We did buy our tickets ahead of time though not sure that was necessary especially during the month of November. It was not particularly crowded. We did have to get the audio guide at a different location than the entrance and you do have a couple of options. They can provide you a guide or you can download it on your phone which is what we did, and they give you a password. There is a small gift shop at the end of the museum as well. Would definitely return the next time we are in Barcelona. Enjoy.

top_reviews.title: Great museum
top_reviews.review: This is a comprehensive and worthy museum full of Picasso's artwork. We also got to view Miro's works. It was quite crowded, so be prepared to wait to see some popular works. Overall, it was worth the time and money.

top_reviews.title: Good family experience in nice setting
top_reviews.review: We went with 3 adult children and the entire family enjoyed the museum. It was not overly crowded in January, and there was also a temporary exhibit focusing on the friendship (and paintings) of Miro. The museum is housed in an appropriately rustic space in Barcelona. Weâre not Picasso experts but it was good to see his development, beginning with his very early paintings.

top_reviews.title: Evolution of Picasso
top_reviews.review: Our visit on a January evening was not very crowded which allowed us to leisurely walk through the exhibits at our own pace. Our tickets were easily purchased in person at the desk and our college student daughter got 50% off for showing her student ID. Adult admission was 15 Euros. First of all the buildings that housed the museum had their own charm and character that was a good setting. Rooms were laid out chronologically to show track how Picasso skills evolved from childhood through his adult life. There were a lot of helpful signs in each room that summarized the period in his life as well as next to featured artwork. The special exhibit this month featured a fellow local artist, Joan Miro, which was also nicely organized that we may see his museum if thereâs time. We spent over an hour here before jet lag took over and we headed back to our hotel.

top_reviews.review: We booked Suntransfers very late but they managed to accommodate us. The car and driver were clean and presentable and the driver friendly and took our cases. The cost was very reasonable for a 45 min return journey. Would definitely use this company again.

top_reviews.title: Superb service!

top_reviews.title: On your way to the Ciutadella Park
top_reviews.review: The Arc de Triomf in Barcelona was designed by architect Josep Vilaseca i Casanovas and built as the main access gate for the 1888 Barcelona World Fair. It showcases Neo-MudÃ©jar style with reddish brickwork. The arch's design, unlike traditional triumphal arches, lacks a military theme. Notably, the arch's two pillars feature stone carvings of bats, the emblem of King Jaume I. Additionally, above the four entrance gates, one can find the coats of arms representing the 49 provinces of Spain.

top_reviews.title: Tall and an Entrance to the Park
top_reviews.review: We were staying nearby, so we walked past this big arch many times. There is a Metro station here. The Arch is an entrance to a big park that contains a zoo and some botanical gardens. The Arch is very tall and you won't miss it.

top_reviews.title: Great backdrop for pictures!
top_reviews.review: I like seeing historic structures such as the Arc de Triomf so we took a route to Ciutadella Park that let us walk down to see it at the same time. It is larger than I realized from photos and I found it impressive. There is protective netting on parts of it, but from a distance that is not very noticeable. It is a nice area for a stroll and a great location to take pictures. Even though it is a busy place with lots of people around, it is a large enough area that we did not feel crowded. If you are not someone who is interested in such things, I would not go out of my way to see it but if you are in the area it is definitely worth visiting.

top_reviews.title: Impressive Arch well worth a look close up.
top_reviews.review: This is an impressive arch designed by architect Josep Vilaseca i Casanovas as the main access gate for the 1888 Barcelona World Fair as others have mentioned. You will see it if you take the open top tourist busses, but it is worth seeing close at hand and makes a good walk when combined with a walk along the Passeig de LluÃ­s Companys to the impressive El Parc de la Ciutadella. We did it the other way round several times back to our hotel in the El Born district from the beach front through the park, along the avenue to the arch asyou then get the vista along Passeig de LluÃ­s Companys to the Arch at the end.

top_reviews.title: It's impressive, but couldn't they come up with an original idea?!
top_reviews.review: The huge Arc de Triomf was built to serve as the main access gate for the 1888 Barcelona World Fair. It would have certqinly provided a grand entrance to the exhibition. But couldn't they have come up with an original idea without copying the famous Arch in Paris?

top_reviews.title: Passing by
top_reviews.review: Our family of two adults, a 9 year old and a 7 year old visited Barcelona for 3 days in July. We visited here one weekday afternoon. We stopped by the Arc de Triomf on our way to the nearby park but unfortunately it was cordoned off in the aftermath of an event or concert. Still nice for a photo opportunity.

top_reviews.title: Impressive site, ideal for a quick visit
top_reviews.review: Great for a quick visit. Imposing and definitely a look with photos. Maybe best seen from one of the cafes across the road for maximum relaxation. From there you can admire the Arc and people watch for an hour or so. Worth a walk down to the park / zoo from here as it really doesn't take long.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful area
top_reviews.review: A beautiful landmark in the city and a great area to spend some time relaxing watching the world go by. Thereâs loads of seating, plenty of restaurants and bars nearby, and its a shame itâs not as âfamousâ as it should be. Definitely worth the time to visit and a highlight of the city.

name: Old Monastery of Sant Pau del Camp
description: The old monastery of Sant Pau del Camp is one of the most important Romanesque sites preserved in Barcelona and one of the most unknown architectural treasures of the city. The church is the oldest preserved in Barcelona and its cloister is unique in Europe because of its polylobuled arches.

top_reviews.title: Excellent vibrant square
top_reviews.review: This a very popular tourist and busy square. It comes to life at night. The perimeter is scattered with bars restaurants and clubs. We dined at a lovely restaurant nad you will find many different types of performers.

top_reviews.title: Sit in History and Savor It All
top_reviews.review: On our visit to Barcelona we knew the Placa Reial was on the list of must see places. After a full morning of Goudi and scenic views of the city from every corner, we just happened to stumble into the Placa Reial. Easy check mark and such fun! We were able to get a table at one venue for lunch right on the square, and another great seat from a different vantage point for dinner and had great meals while being entertained by the various street performers who do their show for the hopes of a Euro or two (or more) by the viewers. So much activity and fun just to watch the people as you take in the history of your location and all that has happened in this incredible space. Recommend you bring coins for the performers and space on your camera for the many pictures you will want to take. Also, a good size appetite for the many, many good options all around the square to eat and sip through the afternoon and into the night!

top_reviews.title: Lively square best in evening
top_reviews.review: Our family of two adults, a 9 year old and a 7 year old visited Barcelona for 3 days in July. We had dinner at a restaurant in this square one weekday evening (see separate review). Placa Reial is a busy hub of restaurants with some small market stalls in the centre next to the fountain. It comes alive in the evening. You'll find this sure just off Las Ramblas about half way down/up. Make sure you look up around the beautiful building exteriors.

I didn't understand the purpose of the small tablets at first, so that could have been better explained. The immersive film at the end was really cool.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful building
top_reviews.review: What a cool place. This was a very interesting building and great art work. We booked fast track online and arrived during our time slot. We got the audio guide, which comes with an iPad and if you look around the room it uncovers some hidden surprises. It was not over crowded and when we got to the roof had a drink at the bar. What a cool experience.

top_reviews.title: An absolute must see!
top_reviews.review: Casa Battlo will take your breath away. Antoni Gaudiâs innovative architectural design plays form with functionality. Every element of the Casa Battlo delights your eyes while performing its physical duties. The Gold pass is well worth the investment. Be certain to go to the roof to enjoy Barcelona!

The immersive experience at the end was short but brilliant and my little boy loved that bit! The queues for the blue tickets looked very long but I didnât have to wait at all with the gold ticket.

top_reviews.title: Busy but enjoyable!
top_reviews.review: Booked tickets in advance and booked the no-frills blue option. Had to queue for about 20 mins, but no problem and very well organised. It was busy, so be prepared and just go with the flow! The audio guide was good, quite bizarre at times, but I enjoyed it! There is a bar on the roof top, but we didn't get a drink so don't know how much it was. You can also pop your head out of a balcony and pay for a photo, but we didn't do that either The cube experience at the end was great and a bit of a bonus! top_reviews.title: Excellent familyâs tour

top_reviews.title: Taste of life in Barcelona
top_reviews.review: Great city park used by tourists and locals of all ages. We could have spent hours watching how local people use the green space for playing guitars, saxophone, practise tight rope walking, sing and so much more. Entertainers around the beautiful fountain were encouraging children to burst huge bubbles while their parents sat in the cafe area. All that and there's still the zoo and museums to visit! A must to visit.

top_reviews.title: Relaxing park
top_reviews.review: Wonderful relaxing park to walk or sit. We watched many locals and tourists all enjoying the park some socialising,reading, children playing and many excellent musicians which were very entertaining. The water features were not working due to the water shortages which was a shame. A must if you want to take some quiet time away from the hustle of the city.

top_reviews.title: Plenty Going On
top_reviews.review: Some more relaxing surroundings away from the busy city, don't get me wrong it's still busy here but at least you have a little bit of nature to chill you out a bit. The centre piece of the parc is definitely the fountain which takes on an even more appealing appearance on a hot summer day. In addition to the fountain you have a Zoo, the Catalan Parliament containing the Art Museum and the Geological Museum. Occasionally you'll have some music on the band stand and see people dancing. If you wanted to you could easily spend a few hours here. Definitely worth a visit whether its to chill out on the grass and read a book all morning or just take 10 minutes to photograph the fountain.

top_reviews.title: A great place to relax
top_reviews.review: Itâs a very big park with stunning views . Plenty of locals doing aerobic or playing games . There are very gorgeous statues and a fountain with ducks swimming which is a great place to take pictures. I would highly recommend for people to take a stroll .

top_reviews.title: Beautiful
top_reviews.review: Lovely place , highly recommend if you like to walk and see art . The buildings and the park itself is just amazing . We visited in April of 2024 and the prices were â¬13 I do recommend also buying the tickets online pages like get your guide or something of sort as the ques at this park can get a bit long . Make sure your wearing comfortable clothing and walking shoes as there are stairs and hills so be prepared .

top_reviews.title: Nice park with lots to see.
top_reviews.review: A nice park to stroll around in, with lots of different paths to take and things to see. We entered on the Arc de Triomf side and walked down to the zoo. It was very crowded on a sunny Sunday afternoon, full of locals and tourists alike. A lot of the area around the parliament building and gardens was fenced off which was unfortunate, but we did get to visit the newly reopened greenhouses (free of charge). You can rent rowboats on a little pond and there are lots of little green parrots flying around which was nice to see. The highlight of the park for me was the large water feature/monument (La Cascada). It was significantly bigger than I thought and just stunning. The emergency measures caused by the ongoing drought meant the fountains were not operating, but it was still amazing to behold.

top_reviews.title: Nice walk
top_reviews.review: Lovely park. The entrance is great and the monument is beautiful. We saw also some elderly persons dancing. What was a nice surprise was at the back of the park, after you pass the second lake with boats and you go for the parliament. Well, be prepared and take some seeds with you as you will find the green parrots. And they can come to pick from your hand.

top_reviews.title: Parc de la Ciutadella ,a green oasis in Barcelona!!!
top_reviews.review: Beautiful parc ,near the Arc of Triomf in Barcelona.The Parc de la Ciutadella is a green oasis in the city of Barcelona. You can take long walks ,have a picnic or take a boat on the lake. In the Parc de la Ciutadella, there are many attractions: the zoo, the Catalan Parliament.

name: Hash Marihuana & Hemp Museum
description: Uncovering the Past, Present and Future of the Cannabis PlantThe Hemp Museum Gallery is located in the centre of Barcelona in the Palau Mornau, a stunning edifice built in the 15th century, which was remodeled by modernist architect Raspall in 1908. It offers a unique permanent exhibition, on the development of the cannabis plant as a versatile source for industrial, nutritional, medicinal, sacramental and recreational purposes. The collection consists of rare items that founder Ben Dronkers, over the past forty years, collected throughout the world. The museum focuses on modern citizens, who despite repressive government measures, are not deterred, to gain knowledge about this particular plant independently.

name: CosmoCaixa Museum Of Science
description: CosmoCaixa offers its visitors a whole host of activities and permanent and temporary exhibitions to give anyone who is interested a greater insight into the world of science. The museumâs most distinctive attractions include the new permanent exhibition âThe Universe Galleryâ where visitors can learn about the cosmos and its evolution from the big bang to the present day. The "Flooded Forestâ recreates the ecosystem of the Amazon inside a glass house covering an area of 1,000 m2, which is home to piranhas, crocodiles and other animal and plant species typical of the area, and the âGeological Wallâ consists of seven vast sections of genuine rock that allow us to interpret the worldâs geology.

top_reviews.title: Criminally underrated, great for kids and adults!
top_reviews.review: I feel this place is criminally underrated. I visited in the afternoon of a weekday and it was relatively quiet. My friend and myself went not knowing what to expect and ended up spending the better most of 3 hours here! Very fun, very interactive, great appeal for kids as well as grownups. Everything is wrote in many languages for tourists to enjoy. Currently looks like they are working on a dinosaur display. The flooded forest section was a particular favourite part. I'd highly suggest this to anyone remotely interested in any form of science, although my friend who isn't so interested in it thoroughly enjoyed herself and how interactive everything is. Great for kids and adults! Unfortunately didn't have time to book the planetarium but it needs to be booked in advance (can be done when buying entry tickets or online) - definitely looked worth it!

top_reviews.title: A place for curious people of all ages
top_reviews.review: Note that about 90% of the exhibits are on the bottom floor so make sure to take your time there and not rush to other floors. We spent 2:30h and I feel like we got to interact with most of the exhibits. Some parts of the museum to be reserved for school activities only. Great place for learning but also just admiring the exhibits. Although I study a scientific subject in uni I still had a lot of fun and managed to discover at least one new fact. The exhibits shine through their interactive nature. The little habitat including trees , fish and birds was gorgeous. Great place for people of all ages who have a curious nature.

top_reviews.title: A must go to for kids and adults alike.
top_reviews.review: This place is amazing! A huge building with umpteen exhibits to suit all ages. The museum has a dinosaur section with some fantastic skeletons, a wildlife area recreating a rainforest with fish/birds/reptiles/mammals and flora. Other areas include the evolution of man, how the human brain and body works and tens of interactive displays from Newton's cradles to sound waves to how volcanoes form. We didn't go in the planetarium as didn't realise it was extra â¬6 each. The cafe was reasonably priced. The only negative was the half hour queue to pay and the walk up the steep hill to get there (there is a tram/bus though). We spent about 4 hours there and still didn't see it all.

top_reviews.title: 10/10 highly recommend even for adults
top_reviews.review: It was really fascinating experience for us both me and my husband. We visited on March 25 at about 16:00 and spent about 10 minutes in line. 6 euro per person only, I would have paid even more. There are fish, plants, an aquarium, animals, dinosaur skeletons, and interactive stands explaining the laws of physics. We spent about three hours at the exhibition. There is also a cafe for snacks, clean toilets, and free lockers for coats or bags.

top_reviews.title: Brilliant day out!
top_reviews.review: Visited as a family of 4 with our two children. Had a great time. The exhibits were interactive and interesting, and the kids really enjoyed it, especially the dinosaur bones and the interactive exhibits. Something for everyone there, and the food was reasonably priced and quite tasty at lunch time in the square.

top_reviews.title: Amazing
top_reviews.review: What an amazing science museum this is. So much to see and do with so many interactive displays. It's not just boards of text (though there are information boards explaining the display) but instead it's more like you're doing experiments so that you can understand what it's trying to show. The flooded rainforest in particular is simply amazing. The best museum we've been to and the highlight of our trip to Barcelona

name: Diagonal Mar Centro Comercial
description: Opened on November 20th of 2001, the iconic Diagonal Mar, owned by a public fund of DWS and managed by CBRE, is one of the largest shopping centres in Catalonia, with 90,000 m2 of gross leasable area (GLA) and more than 200 fashion retailers, restaurants, leisure and services. In addition, it offers 4,800 car park spaces totally free for 3 hours. Recently, the centre was refurbished and modernized in order to adapt it to the new needs of consumers and industry trends.

name: Reial Monestir de Santa Maria de Pedralbes
description: The Royal Monastery of St Mary of Pedralbes, founded in 1326 by Queen Elisenda of Montcada, third wife of James II of Aragon, provides a unique cultural and historical record of the community of Poor Clare Nuns who lived there practically without a break from 1327 to 1982. Its artistic heritage has become a reference for the study of the customs, fashions and models of secular and religious life. The exhibitions "Petras Albas", "The Treasures of the Monastery," "Plants, Remedies and Apothecaries", "Murals in the Spotlight: the Paintings in St Michael's Chapel" as well as the restored Chapel itself, illustrate the museum complex.

I just wish the setup didn't make you feel quite so rushed through it - you get an audioguide to take you through the house, but you have to be part of a guided tour in order to walk through, and the pacing of the audioguide is controlled by the tour guide. Which means unfortunately you don't get to linger and admire, or go through at your own pace. It was a great place to visit, but would have preferred to be able to go through on my own.

top_reviews.review: I came in the evening about 90 min before the closing time, but managed to get a guided tour with a few others. I had the "Barcelona Card Modernista" so did not need a reservation. It was an interesting layout and fun to go through. There is also a small shop to purchase their delicious chocolates! Worth a visit if you have the extra time.

top_reviews.title: Love Gaudis unusual architecture
top_reviews.review: Casa Amatller Casa BatllÃ³ and Casa LleÃ³-Morera make up three interesting buildings showcasing Gaudi's works. Casa Amatler was originally constructed in 1875 for an archaeological enthusiast Antoni Amatller. He passed away in 1910 but his daughter kept this place until 1960 when she passed away. As the original family kept this building for so long the interior remained original. Its role now is that it serves as a historic house, museum, cafÃ©, and anda an Institute for Hispanic Art. Scheduled tours are available.

top_reviews.title: Casa Amatller
top_reviews.review: This was an unexpected gem that we kind of stumbled upon. It is right next to Casa BatllÃ³, which is very busy. The lines for Casa BatllÃ³ are long, the price is a little steep. Casa Amatller is about 20â¬, itâs an audio-guided tour that lasts about 45 minutes. The house is beautiful, still in tact and in original state. Thereâs a wonderful cafe attached with great outdoor seating and an optional art exhibit that seemed very popular, we didnât do that because we had a schedule, and itâs an additional fee.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful and peaceful space next door to Casa Batllo, great Sorolla exhibit
top_reviews.review: We went specifically to visit the Sorolla exhibit, which was wonderful. It had a section on the artist's life and work, another section where you can create your own art work and have your "portrait " done, an immersive area surrounded by Sorolla's work, and finally a virtual experience. Well worth the visit. We did not visit the house, that is a separate ticket. But we did go by the peaceful Cafe on the patio, don't need a ticket for that and it is the perfect place to relax and get away from the crowds in Paseo de Gracia. There are also some tables inside in what it used to be the kitchen, and a nice gift shop. Don't miss the beautiful staircase and stained glass in the entrance way. Again, no need to buy a ticket to see that, but the rest of the house must be beautiful as well.

top_reviews.title: A glimpse into the architectural past
top_reviews.review: Went on a small group tour that was included with my Barcelona Modernista card entry (get it, itâs great!) and was amazed at how well preserved this place is. Itâs a special glimpse into the past that celebrates the building and the people that lived in it. The architecture was so unique and staff were really friendly and helpful.

top_reviews.title: Awesome chocolate and experience
top_reviews.review: We had a fun time and chocolate was awesome. The house tour is worth it, but pay attention to the times thereâs usually guided tours every morning in different languages (catalÃ¡n, Spanish and English). There are some times that they will give you a small gift so look into it.

top_reviews.title: Breathtaking
top_reviews.review: I highly recommend touring Casa Amatller. While Iâm a huge GaudÃ­ fan, I was blown away by this gem designed by Josep Puig i Cadafalch in 1900. Itâs a bit of a hidden treasure, so I got to explore it with just two other people, making the experience even more special. The tour was a fun mix of a staff-led walkthrough and audio guide. Casa Amatller is a dazzling example of Catalan modernism, perfectly preserved with all its original furniture and dÃ©cor. The only thing missing is the original owners, Amatller and his daughter Teresa, whose stories add so much charm to the visit. Every inch of the house is a work of art, with incredible details that are breathtaking.

The promenade is lined with charming cafes and restaurants, providing the perfect backdrop for a delightful meal or drink. It's a great place for families, friends, and solo travelers to soak up the sun, play volleyball, or simply enjoy the vibrant Mediterranean vibe. With clean facilities and stunning views, Bogatell Beach is a must-visit for anyone looking to enjoy Barcelona's coastal charm.

top_reviews.title: Excellent City Beach
top_reviews.review: I read that this is one of the best beaches in Barcelona, and it didn't disappoint. Relaxed atmosphere, clean, and excellent service from the nearby Bo Kaap restaurant. It takes a little more effort to get to than the beaches closer in town such as Barceloneta, but it's well worth it.

top_reviews.title: the best beach in the city
top_reviews.review: Definitely the best beach to visit if youâre in the city. Itâs less gentrified, cleaner, and more beautiful. top_reviews.title: Beautiful Beach
top_reviews.review: Awesome beach! Away from the main beach! Super clean and everyone was friendly! You can use near by beach clubs if you want to rent beds and/or get food and drinks! We spent a whole day here and it we had a great time!

top_reviews.title: Well Functioning Cruise Port
top_reviews.review: This is where we arrived on our big cruise ship. They have room to berth at least 5 big ships at a time, and since this is a popular port, it is usually busy. Everything works well. We were on our way quickly with a short cab ride through the port and into the city.

top_reviews.title: Huge Port, Lots of Cruise Ships
top_reviews.review: Busy, busy place with all the shipping going on. It is a major port of entry for Europe and this port is a workhorse, employing many people. For us, it was the cruise ship experience and the port can accommodate many ships. Crowds, but it is all managed well. If you are departing try to find out exactly where your ship is docked, as it is a big area.

top_reviews.title: Large cruise port. Short taxi from city
top_reviews.review: We took a taxi from the city centre to here (around â¬30). The port area is huge with plenty of room for multiple ships at the same time. The taxi dropped us right at the baggage drop area for the Sun Princess. The baggage drop wasnât as smooth as many US ports with a long queue to hand your bag to one single desk, but it moved fairly quickly.

top_reviews.title: Great exhibits, stadium under construction
top_reviews.review: The stadium itself is under construction until 2026. They advertise that you get a view of the construction of the stadium, which is true but is really nothing worth visiting. The museum itself is quite nice. You get an audio guide which tells you a lot about the history of the club and the exhibits on display. There is also an immersive video feature at the end of tour as well as some interactive displays. Worth a visit, even if you're not a big FCB fan.

top_reviews.title: Great experience
top_reviews.review: We visited the FCB Museum/cafe/gift store. Overall, the museum is great with lots of history and things to see. Even if you don't particularly like football it's incredible to see how much this team has achieved in person. It took us around 30 minutes to go through the museum although we didn't use the audio guide/stop and read absolutely everything. We then went to the construction viewpoint although honestly, you can't see much of the stadium - you cannot enter the stadium at the moment (December 2023) due to the ongoing construction work. The cafe is very standard - they don't have much choice and I felt it was more expensive than other places in Barcelona. However, we were able to get souvenir cups with our drinks for â¬1,50 each which was a nice touch. The store is huge and covers several floors. It definitely had the best range of FCB items of all the stores we visited. However, we did notice that on entering the area there were 2 unofficial stalls selling replica kits/scarves and other items. The scarves from them were cheaper than in the store. We also paid â¬6 per person for 3 shots at the Robo Keeper. I felt this was quite expensive and underwhelming. Overall, I would recommend visiting, especially if you're a football fan.

top_reviews.title: A must-visit for any football fan
top_reviews.review: Camp Nou is the home of FC Barcelona, one of the most successful football clubs in the world. The stadium is absolutely massive, with a capacity of over 99,000. I had the chance to visit Camp Nou for a La Liga match, and it was an unforgettable experience. The atmosphere at Camp Nou is electric. The fans are incredibly passionate and supportive, and they create a truly unique atmosphere. The stadium itself is also very impressive. It's modern and well-maintained, and it provides a great view of the pitch. If you're a football fan, then Camp Nou is definitely worth a visit. It's an iconic stadium with a rich history, and it's sure to provide you with an unforgettable experience. Tips: Book your tickets in advance, especially if you're visiting for a big match. Arrive early to soak up the atmosphere. Take a tour of the stadium to learn more about its history. Wear comfortable shoes, as you'll be doing a lot of walking. Be prepared for the crowds!

top_reviews.title: A vast stadium with lots of history in the museum. Recommended
top_reviews.review: This stadium is quite the spectacle, with lots of history. The museum was incredible to walk around as was the vast stadium itself, it was also enjoyable sitting in the dugout. We also appreciated challenging the robokeeper (I don't like to brag but apparently I was the only person to score that day). A fun experience, recommended if you're in Barcelona.

top_reviews.title: Excellent glimpse into the story of Barcelona FC
top_reviews.review: We visited with two boys aged 10 and 8. Although the Nou Camp is under constriction and therefore not open, we had a brilliant trip. The museum is excellent and really well done, and the virtual tour and Robokeeper are great fun. We spent a morning there and werenât disappointed with any of it.

description: The European Museum of Modern Art , MEAM, exhibits the finest Contemporary Figurative Art. It is owned by TheFoundation of Arts and Artists, and the purpose is to promote and diffuse Figurative Art of the 20th and 21st Centuries. Moreover, the Foundation of Arts and Artists, organizes each year the Figurativas Painting and Sculpture Awards, and with the wesbiteFigurativas en Red opens a window with the artworks of the Contemporary Figurative artists. The MEAM is currentlly located at the Gomis Palace, in the middle of the streets of the Born in Barcelona, a neighborhood where culture is always present and reflects the charm of the old part of the city, an area that knew how to mix tradition and modernity, becoming a requiered visit for the tourits interested in the Monumental Barcelona. These artworks are hardly seen in other museums, collections or entities, to whom the word Contemporary is identified by experiment and abstraction.

top_reviews.title: Don't miss this
top_reviews.review: One of the best art galleries I have been to. Earlier in the day we went to the Picasso gallery which was ok and also the MOCO gallery that was overpriced, small and disappointing having been to the one in Amsterdam. At a bargain â¬12 and spread over three floors it was excellent. Don't be put off with the word modern in the title of the museum, it is not modern art as the Tate gallery in London. There was fantastic thought provoking art and sculptures throughout. On the top floor there was a series of paintings by Haitz de Diego depicting the war of Syria each with a brief poem /explanation of the art. The other two floors were for me spell binding at each turn. We did not need to pre book and the art gallery was quiet with plenty of room to admire the exhibits. I did buy the book of the exhibits as a reminder of a great day to reminis over the cold winter days.

top_reviews.title: Accidental delight
top_reviews.review: We actually went to this museum by accident. We had been trying to find MOCO. We didnât regret it for a minute. There is currently an exhibition on by Mark Tennant which is excellent. I believe it ends May 12th. The other exhibits were just amazing. top_reviews.title: Sublime!
top_reviews.review: The exhibition of modern portraits and the 25 year anniversary works from their permanent collection (showing summer 2024) were excellent. I would definitely visit again to see what their curators have chosen to show. One of the best smaller museums to visit in Barcelona and relatively uncrowded to others.

There is a cafe at the bottom of the park it was really busy. The flowers and plants were nice to see as well

top_reviews.title: Amazing Architecture
top_reviews.review: Visited this beautiful parc - Make sure you book before you go as it gets very busy. It was fabulous seeing the Gaudi architecture. Also, most of the park is dog friendly, so we were able to bring our small poodle and enjoy exploring most areas with him. In some portions of the park, dogs are not permitted.

top_reviews.title: Colours & Space
top_reviews.review: Amazing thought went into creating these gardens, from the aesthetics to the engineering behind the structure and irrigation. The tour guide was also very informative and shared about how imaginative Gaudi was in his use of materials and what he tried to portray. Just wished it wasnât so hot!! top_reviews.title: Hilly Adventure in a beautiful Park
top_reviews.review: Beautiful park! Our biggest complaint was directions. I didnât feel like each section was actually labeled and it was hard to navigate. There was a limited amount of people allowed to enter and we literally bought the last tickets.

top_reviews.title: Very Modernista, saddening - and crammed

We had a guided tour and likeluy got a pretty good information (though the guide appeared less-than-enthusiastic or just plain bored) Worst part was the evergreen tourist catch-22: There were FAR too many visitors, i.e. the place was completely crammed and it became quite difficult to move around. top_reviews.title: This park is quite peaceful despite the crowds and the buildings are amazing!

The Park has a circuit that takes you to all points of interest so you don't miss anything It's a bit tricky to get to on the Metro, but there is a bus from Placa Catalunya that will drop you at the side entrance. Buy your entrance ticket before you go! If you want to get in before the tour groups, buy at least a week ahead.

top_reviews.title: The tour guide was more interested in keeping us in a straight line than giving a tour.
top_reviews.review: First, the park. It's fine. It's interesting and weird and strange. Not very "botanical". The history is interesting and some of the views of the city are wonderful. Would I every go back? No. And our English tour guide was awful - clearly irritated to be there and was much more concerned with our walking patterns than providing information. Meh.

Be aware that you have to be there on time, even if you are late 2 minutes not by your own mistake, but because of the malfunction of gps coordinates (given at the purchased ticket) and misguided info given by the staff at the other Park entrance, you will be met only with a bad attitude and lack of any good manners. Also, big kudos to the certified guide in Spanish Mr.Stephen Carvajal, who saved the day, both to us and to the Belgium familly. He was resonable and professional and led the tour perfectly. Since a significant number of people didn't show up in his group (I assume for the same reasons as in our case), he let us in with him. Whatever is the reason of being late 2 minutes that day, upgrade of gps in the whole city, wrong guidance, mistake by the taxi driver, or even our own (which is not the case here), you should be trained to treat people nice and in a professional way. top_reviews.title: Old Working Class Neighborhood
top_reviews.review: It's an old and traditional neighborhood located by the sea. It's a flat part of town and is easy to walk around. Has been working class and is dense and full of old apartment buildings. Now it is overwhelmed with tourist. Still, one needs to take a stroll here as it is full of atmosphere.

top_reviews.review: Barceloneta Beach is the perfect escape from the cityâs hustle and bustle. The sandy beach and refreshing Mediterranean waters are inviting. I would definitely recommend a browse though and decide for yourself what your favourite area is.

top_reviews.title: Don't miss el Born
top_reviews.review: El Born was my favorite area of Barcelona. It has hip stores, art galleries and restaurants, in an older part of the city. I wouldn't recommend against walking down Las Ramblas, but check out el Born and you'll see why it's better.

top_reviews.title: Charm, Coffee
top_reviews.review: One of my favorite neighborhoods, very old, full of charm, yet very safe and in very good condition. Full of typical restaurants and cafes, so a good place to eat and drink. Good for pedestrians. Come and get lost.

top_reviews.title: Not as artsy as Iâd hoped
top_reviews.review: We expected more art shops and galleries. But itâs a nice walk with tight streets and side streets with lovely balconies and architecture. A few places to eat and basically a relaxing stroll for a couple of hours. Finding a bathroom without sitting to eat a meal is a challenge!

top_reviews.title: A bit of Old Barcelona well worth exploring
top_reviews.review: El Born is sandwiched between La Ribera to the north and Barceloneta to the south with Via Laietana as its border with the Gothic district to the west. Our hotel was on Via Laietana so we explored it most days and nights especially as, although it has a reputation for art galleries, pricey boutiques and shoe shops it is also home to several decent small traditional tapas bars and a couple of the cities burgeoning craft beer bars. Itâs a maze of narrow roads and interconnecting alley ways opening up to the occasional squares, such as the one that houses the impressive BasÃ­lica de Santa Maria del Mar. For me, outside of a couple of quirky art galleries I didnât really pick up on the expensive shops side, but certainly more the bars and restaurants. For those into craft beer DIECI8 Bar and the fairly recently opened Barna Brew Born are two craft beer bars well worth searching out. And there are several authentic tapas bars which are frequented by the locals and tourists alike. I found it a perfectly safe area to explore both during the day and at night, but like various other areas of Barcelona where tourists congregate pickpockets and scammers work here. So just have your wits about you and your possessions tucked away and you will be fine. The El Born district technically stretches east far enough to include the Parc de la Ciutadella which is a fantastic green space and a pleasant area to stroll when the sun is out for a contrast to the narrow streets of the rest of the El Born district.

top_reviews.title: Excellent

top_reviews.title: Santa Maria del Mar
top_reviews.review: This church was built between 1329 and 1383, and it is an outstanding example of pure Catalan Gothic. I bought the full entrance, that gives access to the church, the crypt, the balconies and the roof, and the upper gallery. All parts were very beautiful, except the crypt, which is totally naked. From the balconies and roof there is a spectacular view over Barcelona (158 steps, no lift).

top_reviews.title: Accessible Church
top_reviews.review: There were two admission options to see the church. The basic entry ticket was just to see the inside of the church and the crypt while the other option allowed a visitor to climb up to the rooftop. The inside of the church was a bit on the dark side even with the beautiful stained glass windows up high. It was quite impressive with the towering ceiling above. I liked the fact that most of the small side altars could be seen up close without any gates blocking access like at the Barcelona Cathedral. I recommend skipping the crypt since it was empty save for some tables and chairs. A couple of doors led to other parts of the church that seemed to be storage or an office. A small gift shop was near the admission entrance but not manned. There was minimal signage inside except for one area where a comprehensive description of the church construction was posted. We could understand many of the key descriptions without needing a translator app. We spent around 20 minutes inside for our 5 Euro admission. If you skip going inside then the outside of the church would still be good to walk around. The setting sun seemed to turn the upper portions a golden color. We also saw the Fossar de Les Moreres where the eternal flame constantly burned in memory of those Catalans who fought and died in the Spanish War of 1714.

top_reviews.title: Absolutely my favorite cathedral in Barcelona
top_reviews.review: This cathedral is slightly out of the way compared to the other major tourist sites, but it's so so so so worth it. Hands down, this was actually my favorite one in the city (caveat that this is if you're a fan of gothic architecture). There is a grandeur and a peacefulness that comes through with this cathedral that's incomparable to all the other ones I visited in Barcelona. Also, I loved that there is more freedom with climbing up to the terraces than I've experienced at other cathedrals - you're given instructions on where the stairs are located, but you can go at your own time and your own pace. And in my case, I actually went up more than once, the experience and view from the top was so memorable. There's a wonderful viewing platform that's been set up at the top, with views of the sea.

top_reviews.title: Stunning views
top_reviews.review: Nice church. Paid â¬10 each for entrance and to go to the roof, though no-one checked our ticket to go up. Separate stairs for way up and down, does require some fitness, there is a stopping point about 3/4 quarters of the way up. Stunning views of Barcelona.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful cathedral
top_reviews.review: I booked the tour through GetYourGuide for 10 euros. The young guide was very knowledgeable. Would not recommend for people with limited mobility - there are lots of stairs. The cathedral is beautiful and well worth a visit. Also, read Ildefonso Falcones' book "La Cathedral del Mar" for some background info.

top_reviews.title: Good, but not stunning Catholic church
top_reviews.review: After Gaudiâs La Sagrada Familia and the cityâs towering Gothic Cathedral, this is probably Barcelonaâs third most iconic church. It is tucked away in the historic district of El Born, just a few steps from Via Leietana, which separates the Gothic Quarter from El Born. Allegedly it is the only pure example remaining of the Catalan Gothic style but I will have to take the guide books word for that. What I can say is that Santa Maria del Mar (St. Maryâs of the Sea) is an imposingly place of worship. Internally there is a very impressive rose window framed by twin octagonal towers and be sure to look out for the FC BarÃ§alona coat of arms secreted amongst the stain glass decorations. There is a fee to get inside and it is 5 Euros for the basic entry ticket to see the inside of the church and the crypt and the other includes the climb up to the rooftop. We paid for the basic and it was just about worth it.

top_reviews.title: Interesting interior and history
top_reviews.review: The first day we went to this church it was closed. Since it was close to our hotel we went the next day. I am so glad we got to see the interior. While the exterior is somewhat plain, to my eye, the interior is exquisite with many works of art, stained glass windows and statues. We did not do a rooftop or crypt visit. There are many chapels along the sides with some signage. Take time to explore and learn about the history of this space and really its history in the city. The Basilica web page gives some details you will want to see during your visit. The two most fascinating features for me were the statue and chapel of St. Ignatius Loyola who actually worshiped at this very church and sat in the area where the statue is now. Secondly, the Olympic stained-glass window. It is beautiful. On the outside of the church is also a monument to Barcelona citizens who died in the siege in the 1700's; Fossar de les Moreres, Barcelona. I suggest you take time to appreciate this monument to Barcelona's history.

top_reviews.title: A Hospital That You Really Should Visit!!
top_reviews.review: What a fantastic place to visit! It is a World Heritage Art Nouveau site and well worth the â¬16 entry fee! The hospital was still in use in the early 1990âs but the original concept and building work was from the early 1820âs. Each different building had its own âspecialityâ, one for men, one for women, one for infectious diseases etc. They are being so well restored, itâs awe inspiring in places. There are artefacts from different time periods, including an old X-Ray machine and areas have been set out as to how they would have been utilised. There are also underground tunnels which connect each building that really make you think, how many people have walked through them, how many patients have been transported to a building, how many professionals have had to take a moment. If more hospitals were like this today I donât think many people would mind having to be there!!

top_reviews.title: Historical and an architectural masterpiece
top_reviews.review: This building was formerly a hospital until 2009 and built between 1901 and 1930. The new hospital is built beside this building. The architecure is unique and amazing Art Nouveau) and has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1997. It contains 12 pavilions connected through underground galleries. It really is a historical and architectural masterpiece and offers offers workspace to high-profile social organizations such as the WHO, Banco FarmacÃ©utico, Barcelona Health Hub, EMEA, UN-HABITAT and more.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful Architecture
top_reviews.review: I mean we went after seeing the La Sagrada Familia so it was not as impressive and we did not do the audio guide when the ticket box said not to due to some groups touring today. However, you learn a lot about the history of the place, the hospital care and design at the time. Lots of pavilions which were OK but the architecture was lovely. The main building was gorgeous and if face the main building where you would enter from the back on a sunny day, you can see the reflection of the pavilions behind you and the La Sagrada Familia straight-lined through the windows as well. We spent 1.5hrs here or so and it was worth the admission. We did not buy in advance due to lower season but during higher season; you may want to.

top_reviews.title: Nice Experience Away From the Crowds
top_reviews.review: If you are looking for an experience away from the chaos and crowds of the busy parts of Barcelona, this is your place. Sant Pau is a beautifully restored Barcelona hospital. The various buildings feature stunning architecture and professionally landscaped grounds. You will find Sant Pau to be very quiet and slow paced, which can be a nice respite from busier areas of Barcelona. They offer a high quality gift shop and many shops and restaurants are nearby. NOTE: You can get your ticket here as a combination ticket with the more popular Palau de la Musica Catalan.

top_reviews.title: A Surprisingly Beautiful Building
top_reviews.review: Having visited Barcelona before I thought I'd look a bit further afield for something different and this was on the radar and what a find it was. Built in 1902 and serving as a hospital from 1916 for nearly 100 years, clearly designed to help the patients with their mental health as well with plenty of greenery amongst the buildings. The buildings themselves have beautiful marble interior and are certainly different from any hospital you would have seen. At 16 euro each it wasn't cheap but on a sunny late spring day walking from building to building it was a good way to spend a morning and something a little bit different.

top_reviews.title: Not to be missed attraction in Barcelona
top_reviews.review: With so many must-see attractions in Barcelona, this is usually overlooked and it is a huge loss. It is an amazing site. top_reviews.title: Beautiful and serene

top_reviews.title: Unique experience

top_reviews.title: You wonât regret it!!

Alien movies are good old nostalgia for myself and my husband. Our 12 year old doesnât know much about the movies but he still thoroughly enjoyed the visit. We are so glad we visited. top_reviews.title: A total treat for fans!
top_reviews.review: The collection of memorabilia is vast and impressive, the recreated sets (one for each of the first 3 films!) were incredibly accurate and detailed, and the audio-visual integration of video, sound effects or music playing at just the right point in the tour was flawless. Luis' knowledge of the minutiae of every aspect of these films is encyclopaedic, revealing details about sets, props, costumes, production design, the cast and the Alien itself that are a total treat for fans. Tours are offered separately in both Spanish and English, though as an English speaker only able to attend a time scheduled for a Spanish tour, Luis was brilliant and fluidly switched between both languages to ensure I didn't miss out on anything.

top_reviews.title: Great experience for movie fans!
top_reviews.review: This is an amazing experience for Alien franchise fans, but can be visited with anybody who enjoys listening to stories how the movies were made. You will also enjoy it even if you didn't see the movies! Great, unique pieces;replicas and original props gives this place a superb vibe. Easily reachable by metro, some nice bars for after drinks or lunch around as well. We highly recommend it! Try something different while in Barcelona and surprise your friends!

top_reviews.title: Alien and Me: A Barcelona Experience

top_reviews.review: There are so many things to do in Barcelona that you might forget about the Palace of Catalan Music in the Gothic Quarter not far from the cathedral. But you'd miss out on a unique window into Catalan culture if you did. The auditorium itself is one of the richest and most beautiful in Europe; they say that the acoustics in it are quite special. For 2 euros more, I recommend the guided tour: you'll get to hear the magnificent organ and you'll get a lot of insight into the architect's vision.

top_reviews.title: Modernism at its maximum power
top_reviews.review: The "Palau de la Musica Catalana" is a concert hall that was built in Modernist style between 1905 and 1908. top_reviews.title: Do not miss this experience
top_reviews.review: We visited the Palau Musica on 11/26 for a Flamenco Guitar program, and it was an afternoon that will live in our family's memory forever. As all of the photos convey, the Palau is breathtakingly beautiful. The Art Nouveau attention to detail is evident in every corner, handle, light switch, and finish. Nothing can prepare you for the grandeur and aesthetic overwhelm. It is heaven for art, architecture, and history lovers. Beyond the visual stimuli, the acoustics are heavenly and the show was incredible. While our family is American, we were visiting with an expat family member and their Catalan partner - each of us found the afternoon to be delightful in every sense. Next time, I'd love to take a tour and better understand the history, recurring themes, and construction. But I cannot recommend more highly seeing/hearing a show in the space if your time in Barcelona allows. It will be a treasured memory!

top_reviews.title: Just Beautiful
top_reviews.review: We decided at the last minute to visit and got lucky by joining the last guided tour of the day. It started with a movie in the Petit Palau. We then walked into the original building to visit the foyer. However a private event precluded us from entering and fully seeing it. We climbed the grand staircase and then entered the amazing concert hall. The central skylight up above was truly a sight to see. Even with the storm clouds outside it still let in a lot of light. The decor was modernism that also incorporated musical muses and so glad we could see a lot of it up close. We were also allowed to walk on stage as our guide continued the tour and then setup for a demonstration of the massive organ. The sound was beautiful and hopefully we can come back to enjoy an actual concert. The Lluis Millet Hall was one floor above the concert hall and contained a special art exhibit. Outside was the balcony where many instagrammable photos were taken with the beautiful mosaic columns. We finished the tour on the balcony over looking the concert hall which was a great perspective to see its entirety. We did find the seats not very comfortable though! Outside the fascade of the Palau was also a must see including the statues of many famous composers. It was not as easy to see all the details due to the surrounding buildings and tight street. Our guide used the 2nd floor balcony to point out details in the reflections to the opposite buildingâs windows. This should be a must see when in Barcelona. Well worth the time to see this UNESCO designated building.

top_reviews.title: Amazing experience, catch a live concert if you can.
top_reviews.review: We had been planning on booking a tour but when we found a guitar and flamenco concert for the last night of our trip we booked it immediately. We paid â¬42 each for stall seats, the concert was about 90-110 minutes ( no interval) and it flew by. The music was phenomenal, the dancing superb (especially the male dancer) and the encore was astounding - have you ever seen three guitarists and a percussionist play a Michael Jackson melody on ONE guitar??! The building itself is stunning, and I would like to return in daylight to get the effect of the natural light. Hoever it was nice to see it being used for its proper purpose, not just a museum. The bar/ restaurant looked interesting but of course was very busy.

top_reviews.title: Stunning and colourful
top_reviews.review: Emma took us on a lovely tour of the inside and outside of this stunning building, pointing out some of its secrets along the way. I was delighted to be able to fit this in on my last morning in the city. Cannot wait to return to experience a concert in the magical concert hall.

top_reviews.title: The Heartbeat of Barcelona Culture
top_reviews.review: This place is simply amazing. There are 3 reasons to visit here. First, the palace and concert hall are architectural marvels, treating you to sights and sounds you have never seen or heard before. Second, catching a performance here is very special. We were not able to attend an event in the main hall, but thoroughly enjoyed a classical music concert in the smaller venue. It was outstanding! Third, they feature a really high quality gift shop and a top notch restaurant as well. If in Barcelona, the Palau de la Musica is a must do. NOTE: The self guided tour is designed for mobile device download but can be very sketchy. Be sure and pick up a pamphlet in case the downloaded audio doesn't work.

top_reviews.title: It's great, but be prepared for details.
top_reviews.review: It's great, but be prepared for details. As others noted , if you arrive at T2 it's a bit of a hike to the bus and it is not signposted inside the building. Outside you'll see huge signs, and eventually you'll realize that the one the Aerobus is at is WAY down there. The bus is fine. We got off at Espanya, but you'll probably have similar results at the other stops. Each place is a HUGE circle, and if you're connecting to the Metro, only ONE point on the circle has a lift. Without that, you're schlepping suitcases down stairs, along a LOT of corridors, up stairs, down stairs .... Returning to the airport we just took a cab to Espanya. You're saving so much by taking the bus that it's money well spent.

top_reviews.title: An easy way to get to the City Centre
top_reviews.review: An easy way to get to the centre of Barcelona. A regular service which can get crowded. Bus stop near Terminal 2. Best and cheaper to buy a return ticket which you can get on line before you travel or before you board the bus itself upon arrival

top_reviews.title: great experience
top_reviews.review: Its really a great experience to have. i took aerobus from terminal 1. i booked the ticket from the vending machine which was an easy. the bus took me from airport to plaza catalunya in around 30 mins. the seat is good with a free wifi access. my only concern that there is a lot of passengers was standing as there is no free space to seat.

top_reviews.title: Easy and convenient Aerobus
top_reviews.review: Once you get your luggage from the carousel, you head out to the exit. Follow the signs and you will end up on level 0 to catch the bus. You can easily buy your tickets there (cheaper by a couple of euros) or buy online. Also on level 0, you will find the metro.

top_reviews.title: Efficient way of transporting from the airport
top_reviews.review: Its an efficient and cost effective way of transporting from the airport to the city. The cost was 6.75 â¬ pp and they run every 10 minutes. A taxi covering the same trip could cost 35-40â¬. The stop is outside the airport and we were travelling to our hotel near Placa Catalunya which was around a 5 minute walk to our hotel. It was a comfortable ride.

top_reviews.title: A Cultural Feast
top_reviews.review: Being an Art lover, Barcelona was always going to be a treat, with its many museums and galleries, particularly leaning towards the contemporary. After much thought, we decide to purchase Barcelona Cards, which gave us free transport on the Metro, Busses and local trains. (with certain exclusions such as the Aerobus) as well as free admission to many of the museums. We picked up our cards in the airport terminal and travelled to our hotel on La Rambla by the Metro which has stations at the airport. Our hotel on La Rambla was well equipped, but just a warning; The metro run the length of La Rambla underneath the road. As a train passes, the road vibrates, as do the hotels. Be wary if you are a light sleeper though they finish about midnight to start again about 4.50am. More of a concern was the liveliness of La Rambla itself, with noise coming from the street throughout the night. Our room faced the street and this did cause some problems. On the whole, Barcelona is an amazing city with plenty for all. take time to look at what your preferences are because you will not be able to do everything.

top_reviews.title: Airport transfer on the cheap
top_reviews.review: Great service. Easy to find at the airport. No rush to get on as the buses are so regular. Excellent position of last stop in Placa Catalunya. Be careful if you buy a ticket for a few days unlimited travel on city buses and metro. Although it says clearly on the machine that the airport bus is included, this is not correct.

top_reviews.title: Great link between the airport and Barcelona City Center
top_reviews.review: The Aerobus is an incredibly convenient and inexpensive way to get to the center of Barcelona and from there back to the airport. The service is well marked at the airport, operates 24/7 and leaves every 5 minutes. The buses have wifi and even USB ports at the seats. Stops are announced in advance. Separate buses service T1 and T2 so you don't lose time driving between terminals at the airport; just be sure to know where your flight is leaving from before you board a bus.

top_reviews.title: Good option for travel
top_reviews.review: Great service to and from airport. Where youâre staying does make a difference to how far your onward journey is at the last bus stop so check the map! Good value and friendly drivers. Will definitely use again. Reliable regular service too .

top_reviews.title: Easy transfer between Barcelona Airport and city centre
top_reviews.review: Excellent service from Barcelona Airport to the city centre. I bought tickets online in advance in a very simple transaction. Tickers are accessed through an app. There are also ticket machines if you need to buy at the airport but beware of queues. We exited the terminal, easily found the bus stop directly outside: with buses coming every 5-10 minutes there's no delay. Journey to the centre took about 25 minutes. Fast, comfortable and cheap - also far easier than the metro.

Although we visited in mid-April, the top floor was very hot so you may want to bring a small fan if you do not like the heat. I am glad we made the time to come here and do recommend it if your schedule allows.

Minuses: -The curt service by the front line staff and the downright rude female security staff at the entrance marred the experience. - A clear and concise Directory on the ground floor, indicating what is shown at each level would have been helpful.

top_reviews.title: One of the MUHBA sites
top_reviews.review: We found this museum online before our trip, it was a bit more difficult to locate in town. But finally, we found it. The entry is marked but we missed it going in. There is a cost, but it was minimal - I don't even remember how much. There are several floors to this museum so pick up a map. There is even a below level where more excavation is ongoing. Within the museum there are many signs to identify the displays and most have English translations. Some beautiful pieces on display and much to help explain the long history of Barcelona which we enjoyed. This makes a great way to get to know the history and culture of this beautiful city. Be prepared to spend a couple hours at least.

top_reviews.title: Loads of information!
top_reviews.review: If you want to find out more about Barcelona and its history, this place does a good job. There are a lot of pictures, footage and exhibits with plenty of written information. I have a couple of niggles though. The direction round the place (which is substantially large) is not very clear. My feet and legs were aching after about an hour and a half wandering and stopping to read etc. We didn't see everything. I found the transcription into English a bit annoying as some of it didn't make sense. All in all, worth a visit.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful Views!!
top_reviews.review: The views you got from here were absolutly incredible! Its a shame there is the amusment park infront of it and it does get in the way of some photos. Make sure you have a good wander around to see different areas of Barcelona. We got the L7 metro line to Av. Tibidabo and then walked to the funnicular station which was about 25 minutes. The funnicular on the way up was not worth the ride, which I think was â¬12 each return for adults, the views were better at the top so I'd suggest getting an uber or taxi up if there are several of you as its probably cheaper and you're not missing out on anything. Beautiful views and worth the travel time. The church itself is free to go in but you do have to ay if you want to go up to th top.

top_reviews.title: A Fantastic Church with A Great View
top_reviews.review: A thirty minute taxi drive to right by the church seemed like a sensible way to start the trip, that was until it came time to leave when trying to buy a one way ticket down on the funicular was a nightmare of queueing and miscommunication. Anyway, the church inside is impressive with the usual mix of vaulted ceilings, impressive stained glass and frescos. The real highlight though is up on the roof and the view for miles out across the city and the surrounding forests. A great place to visit if you have exhausted the city centre itself and have young kids that would enjoy the pretty basic amusement park outside the church, if you are sensible and left the kids at home just enjoy the views.

top_reviews.title: Interesting situation
top_reviews.review: Climbed Tibidabo Hill out of Barcelona City on foot through woodland paths and up several steep sections. An enjoyable hike of about 3 miles from the outskirts of the city. Extraordinary to see this church at the top of the hill surrounded by an amusement park!!! Great views of the city and coast. Inside the Basilica is peaceful and serene with lovely stained glass windows

top_reviews.title: Donât come here just for the church. Itâs good but the views of Barcelona is the real star.
top_reviews.review: Normally I would say donât bother with the Temple Expiatori del Sagrat Cor de JesÃºs (Temple of the Sacred Heart of Jesus) as internally itâs a pretty average church compared to others in Barcelona. But much of its attraction comes from its privileged location on one of the highest peaks in the city, from which you get truly excellent views. But once youâve made it up here you might as well take a look at the inside of the church, which oddly is on two levels. The ground level has some impressive frescos and stained glass windows, then the upper level once you climb the steps is more about the columns to the roof space but still has some nice statues and features. However, itâs the views from here that really win the day.

top_reviews.title: Buena Vista Club
top_reviews.review: Worth navigating your way here and best arriving by funicular. Get a ticket to use the lift which will take you to the highest point where the views are fabulous. The theme park was closed so less screeching kids. Inside the church itâs impressive. Fidelscastrol.

name: Gothic Quarter (Barri Gotic)
description: Stroll through the historic center of medieval Barcelona and visit some of the city's most important political buildings and gothic architecture.

top_reviews.title: One of the best areas in Barcelona
top_reviews.review: This is one of my favorite areas of Barcelona. So nice to just walk around, get lost and admire its architecture. They kept its old town charm which is amazing. Lots of local restaurants, bars and shops. Some corners have cool art too. The Cathedralâs exterior here looks amazing. When we went there at night outside the cathedral thereâs a flea market and a street show where this guy jumped above 3 standing people. Bottomline, I will pick this area to stay and stroll any day rather than La Rambla. This just has so much history.

top_reviews.title: A really lovely stroll
top_reviews.review: Possibly the best part of Barcelona so far. It has a wonderful vibe just wandering through the tiny narrow streets. In peak season it might be crowed but when we went in November it was ok. Even better it will cost you nothing.

top_reviews.title: Great area to just wander around
top_reviews.review: This is a very nice area of Barcelona, full of narrow streets and interesting buildings. There are also plenty of people and street performers around. It's great to just wander around and stumble across a nice restaurant or tapas bar. Highlights are the cathedral which is very impressive and the Pont del bisbe which connects two buildings.

top_reviews.title: Amazing timeless stroll
top_reviews.review: Just amazing to walk around without an agenda or a time limit. There is just so much to see and relaxing at a cafe and people watch is just a joy. The architecture is something to be beholden to. I would just set up some dedicated time to enjoy the area and enjoy the culture of the quarter. Enjoy.

top_reviews.title: Old Town Barcelona
top_reviews.review: We enjoyed staying close to the Old Quarter and walking through different parts every day. The small and rambling streets were filled with many old or historical buildings. Some buildings seemed like a jigsaw puzzle having been built by reusing pieces from different eras of Barcelonas history. There were lots of restaurants, bars to eat or drink along with churches, museums to visit and plazas to hang out and people watch or be entertained by street performers. We felt safe walking around here both in the day and night. Nighttime was much less crowded and quieter. It was also nice not seeing and hearing many cars due to the driving restrictions and narrows streets.

top_reviews.title: El Barrio Gotico - un lugar magico
top_reviews.review: The Gothic neighbourhood in Barcelona is very charming. It has narrow streets that smell of paella at night, interesting stories painted on different stones, people trying to sell all sorts of things and many nice secrets. I bought there a silk skirt on sale and ate alone s big paella that I can never forget. I also got blocked in the back of a shop trying on some clothes...with a Pakistani seller that spoke a bad English. But it was fun. The Santa Maria del Mar gothical church is a must for the top views of the Mediterranean Sea from its towers. I love the sea, I love this town. top_reviews.title: My favorite part of Barca.
top_reviews.review: We LOVED this part of the city. Steeped in history, winding little streets with gorgeous balconies, little squares with cafes, shops and bars. The church is also stunning. A must see when in Barcelona away from the hustle and bustle of city life

top_reviews.title: Best area of the city
top_reviews.review: This was our second trip to Barcelona, so we knew we wanted to stay in the Gothic Quarter. There is so much to see within easy walking distance. We saw Roman ruins, plenty of churches and great coffee shops and restaurants. Plenty to see and do. With the museums you get a chance to learn about Barcelona.

top_reviews.title: always include this on your visit
top_reviews.review: Whether you do a walking tour or just wander around, the Gothic Quartar is a must-do. Is it safe? Well, it is crowded, and it is in a big city, so you must use common sense. I've never had an issue and always just kept my wits about me.

top_reviews.title: A Charming and Historic Gem in Barcelona
top_reviews.review: The Gothic Quarter in Barcelona is a must-visit. Its narrow, winding streets are filled with medieval architecture, hidden courtyards, and vibrant squares like PlaÃ§a Reial. Highlights include the stunning Barcelona Cathedral and the Picasso Museum. It's perfect for exploring during the day and enjoying the lively nightlife. Whether you're into history, photography, or local culture, the Gothic Quarter is enchanting and unforgettable.
